segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Thank you for coming to this talk.
I'm going to prep you for lunch.
Hopefully that will relax you later.
I'm here replacing my CTO, Michael, who sadly couldn't come here.
So I'm going to show you work that's mostly his.
I'm not going to take credit for that, but I will be presenting.
So this is Michael.
Michael is our CTO, and he's actually almost the father of low-code, no-code security.
Most of what you'll see on the Internet comes from him.
And he spoke at many conferences.
He's a regular columnist online.
And he's hiring, and that's Michael.
Me, however, I am out of range, apparently.
There you go.
That's me.
I'm a hacker of things, which means I hack pretty much everything.
I'm not limited to software or hardware.
I'm a collector and restorer of all computers.
I also spoke at some conferences, and I'm also hiring.
So if you're an exceptional researcher and this talk made you think, then let's talk.
So why should we invite guests into our organization in the first place?
And what is the promise of deny-by-default access?
Today, when you're a Microsoft shop, if you're a big Fortune 1000 company and you're working
with a Microsoft infrastructure, there are a very limited number of ways with which you
can share information with external factors, let's say a vendor or even a candidate, like
if you want to send them a home assignment or something like that.
So first option is just send them the sensitive emails, and we really don't want to do that.
We're security people, so that's not really good options, although it does sometimes happen.
Another thing you can do is use some service online.
There are all kinds of file drop sites, so you can also use that, but then your content
is being seen by somebody else.
Or you can also just trust a random person on real life.
This is like a real thing.
I'm sure you've seen that.
So it's sort of a thing.
People do that on purpose and share files, and it's a surprise, and I think I've heard
of at least one time that this thing was actually the USB killer, so don't do that.
It's not nice.
Or option three, if you're a Microsoft job, you can invite them into your tenant.
This is the most reasonable option for you to use.
The concept is of an external user that you invite into your tenant, and then you can
share things with them.
I want to remind you that most of the Microsoft platforms are oriented at collaboration and
sharing.
This is a very important factor in all the design decisions that were made.
So in order to have a safe solution to invite guests, there are two conditions that you
need to follow.
The first one is that it has to be easy for vendors to onboard.
If it's too complicated for you to add a new vendor, then it's not going to happen.
It's going to break.
You're going to suffer all kinds of consequences.
Your vendors are not going to want to work for you.
And let's say that you did that, then it has to be controllable.
Your IT security needs to be able to understand it and control it, because otherwise you're
inviting someone into your own tenant, and they're not really a member of the tenant.
They're external.
They're guests.
So let's look at what we see.
So it's super easy to get a guest account.
What you see here, this online video, is of how you invite someone into your tenant.
You just send them an invitation.
That's it.
That's all you do on the inviting side.
So that's super easy.
That's very good.
However, on the receiving side, you get the invitation.
You can click it.
You can go online.
But a very talented researcher by the name of Dirk Jan discovered that you can actually
enumerate invitations that the organization has sent and has not been used yet.
So if you scan an organization and you find a few invitations, you can just grab one of
them and use the token, and you're going to be given credentials to use, but under the
identity of the person that originally received the invitation.
So you're not just getting access to somebody else's tenant.
You're also doing that under their assumed identity.
That's not even you.
And this is a very nice research.
It was published.
It was disclosed.
And it was fixed.
Very, very nice talk.
Yeah.
So it's called non-redeemed invites, and you could do pretty much whatever you want with
it.
After you do that, there's another problem.
Okay.
So you're a guest in the tenant, and now how do you control what you can do in the tenant?
So this is a Microsoft shop, and there is a way that you can bring your other identities
as a way of getting into the tenant.
So in the middle, there is this whole ecosystem of services by Microsoft, which says, okay,
I will trust this third-party IDP, identity provider.
And once they say that you are, you say you are, and if that matches the invitation, then
I'm going to let you in.
And of course, once you have this entire system by Microsoft, then this is what the entire
Microsoft tenant uses for access control.
So as a benefit, you automatically get all the benefits of the Microsoft.
You get the multi-factor authentication, the role-based access control, certificate authorities,
anything you already have in Microsoft can be applied to you, even if you identify through
Google.
And that is very nice.
This sort of solves the problem.
So you need guest access.
You get the required security controls, and those require an AAD account.
Otherwise, you can't do the enforcement because Microsoft services work on top of the AAD,
now called Entra ID.
And theoretically, if you have an AAD account, that would give you full access, right?
You're a member of the tenant, and we don't want that because you're a guest.
You're only here because I need you to be here, right?
I need to share something with you.
So would that solve the problem?
No.
What you want to do is to make sure that the, okay, I need to learn what this range is.
You need to do a policy where guests, by definition, can't see anything.
And then you can give them whatever you want, right?
So that would sort of solve the problem.
Now, allegedly, that's what's happening, okay?
You get an invitation, you join the tenant, and you don't access anything.
That should solve the problem.
However, let's see what actually happens because, as we all know, what you plan is
one thing and what happens is another.
So from now on, I want you to notice this area.
This little icon is going to tell you whether I'm the inviting organization, and that is
going to be green, or whether I'm the hacker, and then that's going to be red, okay?
So this is the vendor, and the vendor would like to invite someone, and that would be
me.
I would be Hacker 5 at Pontoso.
So you send the invitation to the hacker as a guest, okay?
It's important as a guest.
By the way, guest versus member is a property of the Entra ID.
And it's important to understand because it has implication on everything in your tenant,
not just Power Platform, which is mostly what we're going to be showing here today,
but everything else in your tenant.
Now I've switched the icons, okay?
Now I'm the bad guy.
I'm logging into my own tenant.
Everybody can have a tenant.
It's free.
So I'm logging into my own tenant, and then it says, you've been invited by somebody else,
and please approve all the conditions.
And once you do that, here I am.
And as you can see, there's nothing here, right?
I'm a guest, so my access is very limited.
Absolutely nothing for me to do.
So you would think that it works, and most people that don't like saying, but what if,
that's what they see.
This is where they stop.
But not really, okay?
So right up until this talk, there was the state-of-the-art guest exploitation, and what
did it include?
Well, the first thing that you could do is you could do phishing via Teams.
Now Teams is also sort of a sharing and collaboration platform, and it turns out that any tenant
member can send a Teams message to any other tenant member.
And that is a problem because many people, in their perception, look at Teams as something
that is internal to the organization, like Slack or something.
If you get a message on your Slack, which is logged onto your organization, you're automatically
assuming that it is someone from the organization because you got a direct message.
And you don't necessarily realize that it could have come from another tenant, right?
And it turned out that not only that, but through some bypass and some overlook of policies,
you were able to send a file attachment, again, from the outside tenant to the victim tenant.
And that should not happen, but it could happen.
And that opened the door for phishing campaigns over Teams.
And since the medium Teams is trusted, then we have what we call the trust by proxy.
You trust Teams, so everything on Teams is trusted, and you don't even notice that it's
an external message.
And there's also a tool to do that.
This, by the way, is from Microsoft's own blog, right?
Which lets you phish by attachment from external users.
And then you get this message, and how can you even tell it's from someone who's not
in your organization?
Because it looks exactly the same, right?
Let me help you.
Here, it says external, right?
So if you missed that little tiny font, and on top of everything, it's not even in the
content, right?
It's on top.
You didn't notice it was an external user.
You got a file attachment.
You clicked it, and you're done.
Second thing, it turns out that guests are able to do recon on the tenant.
Now, you shouldn't be allowed to do that.
But again, another tool and another talk, and you have AAD internals.
And what you can do is you can enumerate on all the people that are guests, and you get
a list.
And then you can enumerate on the groups that they have access to.
And then it turns out that some of those groups also have lists inside them.
And then you do this iteratively, and you end up getting a recon of your victim tenant,
and you're a guest.
Now, it's true that you didn't access anything yet, but you do have the list, and that's
already a big advantage for an attacker.
But that's not enough.
That was the state of the art until recently, but hackers want more, right?
What do we want to do?
We want to get data we're not supposed to have.
We might want to change the data or just cause damage, right?
These are the three principles of IT security, CIA, confidentiality, integrity, and availability.
Any damage to any one of those, great success for the hacker, tough luck for the victim.
So let's see what we're doing.
Now, at this point, you get the opportunity to say, I don't want to know.
I'm going to go outside, have a drink, start lunch early, because when I go forward, I'm
going to ruin your day, especially if you use Microsoft software.
So anybody leaving?
No?
OK.
So if I click this link, now you can see that I'm the attacker now.
I'm logging into Power Apps, and it doesn't work.
Why?
Because it's not my tenant.
So what do I do?
So this is my tenant.
OK?
So you can see it up here.
OK.
And if you work with that, you know that if you are a member of more than one tenant,
you can switch directory.
So if I switch directory, you can see that I also have the other one.
I'm currently on Pontoso.
I don't know why the resolution is not good here.
It's kind of good on my screen.
Do you want me to turn this around for you?
OK.
And I can switch directory to the Zenity demo.
This is Zenity demo.
Right?
And when you switch the tenant, once you're already logged in, then, whoa, all of a sudden,
I have a list of things.
And what are these things?
If you look at the side, you will see that this is a list of connections.
What do we have here?
We have an Azure Blob Storage, Azure File Storage, Azure Queues, Table Storage, and
two SQL servers.
Why am I seeing those?
Let's look.
OK?
Let's look at this one, Azure File Storage.
It was modified 12 minutes ago, and it's connected.
Everybody knows the distinction between connector and connection.
I'll just do it quickly.
A connector is a mechanism to connect between two locations, for example, your service and
some external data.
And this is just the mechanism.
It's like a translator.
When you take a pair of credentials and you authenticate on top of that connector, you
now have a connection.
Right?
So a connection is basically an authenticated session of the type of the connector.
And these are connections, which means they are authenticated, especially because they're
still connected.
Right?
So if we look at it, I can do the share.
You can always go to the share menu, even if you're not an owner.
You just won't be able to do anything.
And we can see that Jamie is the owner and also has the access of use and share.
I don't.
Right?
But look at this.
Shared with org.
It means this connection was shared with the entire organization.
Now going back to the concepts of tenant and guests, a guest is now inside the tenant.
When you share something with the organization, you're sharing it with the entire tenant.
And anybody in it.
So that's your employees, contractors, guests, anyone.
So anyone in the tenant now has access to this connection.
Okay?
If we look at the details, so these are the details of the connection.
We can also look at this tab that says apps using this connection.
This is Jamie, by the way, the owner of the connection.
Who is Jamie?
Jamie is customer service representative.
It's nice to know.
So you can maybe connect that to the recon you did earlier.
Right?
And why does this happen?
Okay.
I'm going to skip the video.
The reason it happens is that now people are using a lot of local platforms and ever since
November when Microsoft published the copilots, people are no longer actually making decisions.
They use copilots and then they create the whole application on top of connections and
other resources in like five minutes.
And the decisions of what is shared to whom are being made by the automation platforms,
by the copilots.
Now, even before the copilots, I mentioned a number of times already that these platforms
are meant for collaboration.
So when people create something that they think is useful, they want to share it.
Right?
They want to share.
I wrote an app to manage time.
I wrote an app to find a parking spot.
I wrote an app to get movie tickets.
I want to share it with all my friends and colleagues.
So when you create something with a copilot, if you're not paying attention and you're
just clicking all the forward and doing all the defaults, you're going to end up creating
something that is shared with the entire organization.
Now at this point, usually a lot of people say, okay, this sounds serious, but we don't
have that problem.
We didn't teach anybody to do low-code, no-code, so this is not really our problem.
And the problem with that is that it's just not true.
One of the things that we're seeing is that the system administrators, the CISOs in organizations
don't realize and don't know the extent of the use of low-code, no-code.
Now Microsoft estimated that the number of C-sharp, this is from last year, the number
of C-sharp developers in the entire world is roughly 5 million.
Okay, that's really nice.
How many people, according to Microsoft, were using the low-code, no-code services of Power
Apps?
Roughly 8 million.
Now how many resources are you familiar with that go to teaching and educating C-sharp
developers versus what we call the citizen developers, the regular people of your organization
that just do what they're supposed to do?
Almost none, right?
Now if you argue with this graph, and you can do that, then what I have here for you
is the low-code, no-code adoption rate of just four of our customers.
They're not named here, and it doesn't matter.
But what I want you to see are not just the numbers, but the rate.
Because when somebody all of a sudden succeeds in writing an application, and they're not
a developer, maybe they're an accountant, and it works, they get so excited, they tell
their friends, and then this spreads exponentially.
People create more resources, more connections, more applications, more automations, and this
goes really fast, right?
So these are real-world graphs from two months ago.
Now how do we exploit that?
Let's see.
So this is the connection, right?
And what I would want to do is look at the application that is using it.
So apps using this connection, you can see there's an app called Customer Insights Azure.
Now let's try to execute that.
I'm the bad guy, as you can see.
And if I try to execute it, I get blocked.
Why?
It says here, you don't have the current plan to access this app, right?
So yeah, let me read that for you.
It says, you don't have the correct plan to access this app.
Ask your admin for one, or ask the admin at the organization in which you're a guest.
Wait.
You notice the distinction here?
You can ask your admin or the one where you're a guest.
But I have my own tenant, right?
I am the admin and my tenant.
So let's see how that goes.
I'm going to Microsoft, and I'm saying, hi, can I please have a license?
And Microsoft is like, of course.
Why not?
It's your tenant.
Go ahead.
And now you have it, right?
So I can go back, and now I have the plan.
So I can run the application.
But now there's another problem.
Now it says, it looks like this app isn't compliant with the latest data loss prevention
policies.
Uh-oh.
So apparently, Microsoft has DLP policies, which prevent stuff from happening, right?
It says they're the same.
And the question is, what's going on here?
So data loss prevention is supposed to be a service that lets you tag information and
define what can go where and who is allowed to do what.
And it turns out that in Microsoft, it's not exactly that.
So if I were to create a new DLP policy, let's say, find social security numbers, then what
I will do is I will get to choose the connectors.
And in Microsoft Power Platform, every data has a connector to it.
And this includes internal Microsoft services, like Office 365, but also pretty much anything
else outside.
I don't know if you see the number, but there are over 1,000 connectors.
So any sort of data that you're aware of has a connector, and you can even develop
your own.
It's called a custom connector.
But let's put that aside.
So here, I can say, OK, I want to block SharePoint, but there's a problem.
One or more of the selected connectors cannot be blocked.
Is it blockable?
No.
So wait.
What's going on here?
So here's the thing.
If you also notice, it says SharePoint, but it doesn't say whose SharePoint, whose credentials,
which site.
It's just saying SharePoint.
This is actually not associated to a user.
So this is generic.
And you can also tell that by understanding this is a connector, OK?
So I'm reminding you that a connector is just a mechanism.
And without the association with an authentication, it doesn't mean anything.
So this is talking about the connector, and you're not allowed to block the connector
SharePoint.
So how is the DLP even working?
Well, turns out that it doesn't really.
One of the things that we like doing is finding problems in the DLP.
These have all been published.
They're all in our blogs.
And to make a long story short, the DLP is not really DLP.
What it actually is is sort of an access control list on applications and automations.
They somehow forgot the connections.
And this means that I couldn't execute the application because it was in the DLP.
But the connection, what is the connection?
The connection is a SQL server, OK?
Now, if the good guy tries to execute the app, then they have to permit power apps to
use their identification together with the connector and establish a connection, right?
So once you do that, then you can access the application.
This is the application.
That's what it looks like.
Specifically, this was built to work on a mobile phone, but you can also run it on your
laptop.
It doesn't matter.
In ISO, you can see there's a database here, and these are a list of customers, and everything
is working well, OK?
That's a specific customer.
This is all, by the way, chat GPT generated, so don't worry, no PII is here.
Now, if you look in the browser data behind the scenes, you will see all this information.
You will see that there is an actual API call that brings that data.
Now, because the application runs half in the backend server and half on my computer,
the API calls that fetch the data originate in my browser.
I can actually see them.
And if you look at that, it looks like this, and it has a few components.
This is the service that you're calling.
This is actually the API hub that lets you work on top of Microsoft services, and this
is the specific connection that I'm using.
This is the connection ID.
Again, not connector, connection.
It's an authenticated connector.
It is attached to a session and an identity.
And this is the particular service that the connection gives me, right?
Because if you have a connector to an SQL server, everything that the SQL server is
able to do is being published as a service.
This is the actual, let's call it, payload of the command to get.
Now, here I'm getting data, but I could just as well delete data, change data, whatever.
It doesn't matter.
It's all on top of what you already have.
That was just encoding.
This is the exact same thing that you saw in the application earlier.
Now, how does that work?
When you work with the Azure API management and it asks you for your permission to use
your credentials, what it does is it takes your credentials and it stores them in its
own little secret place.
Now, it doesn't share your credentials per se.
No one else gets them.
But the code that actually connects to the SQL server, that's not running on your computer.
That's running in the back end of the API.
So what happens here is that Microsoft takes your credentials, puts them aside, and then
when you try to execute operations, it takes the credentials that you gave it and it attaches
them to the operation.
And the end result is you, or as far as the back end is concerned, someone that looks
like you and identifies as you, is carrying out the operations.
This makes sure that only the privileges that you have are being used.
This makes a lot of sense.
But you remember where this all started, right?
We were sharing this.
So if you're allowed to share an application or share a connection, and the connection
is authenticated, then if somebody else is using that connection, unless they had to
authenticate themselves, the connection is using the original credentials.
So if I'm using this connection, as far as the back end is concerned, it's Jamie.
It's not Hacker 5.
I didn't authenticate.
So this is a big problem, right?
So back in real life, we got blocked.
And if you look inside, you will see that the reason we got blocked is because we didn't
have the permissions, right?
We talked about that.
The DLP blocks applications.
But when you run that in the browsers as a permitted user, not the hacker, the good guy,
it actually works.
So if you look at this information behind the scenes, and you look at the API call,
then you see that this is when you converted it to CURL, right?
You can look at the network traffic in your browser developer tools, and you can convert
that to a CURL command.
And it turns out that the browser on your side is using a bearer token that performs
these things for you, right?
And of course, it probably all makes sense because you're the good user.
But what happens if you're not a good user?
What happens if you copy that little query and you execute that as the bad user?
It also works.
And that is kind of interesting.
Like why would this work?
I am not using the app.
I am not Jamie.
But remember what I said before.
The back end takes Jamie's credentials stored in the secret place, attaches them to whatever
action you're going to do, and then lets you execute it.
And it is here in this bearer token.
Now if we look at the bearer token, we will see that the audience is indeed the API hub,
and the issuer is Microsoft.
So somehow the credentials let me access the API hub.
All right.
Now how can I generate a token for the API hub?
You can generate any token because you can do it with the command line interface.
But there are some limitations.
You can't do it with a built-in public client app because the list of apps that are allowed
to create this token is limited.
It's whitelisted.
So you can't just do that.
Can you do your own app?
Well, no, because of the same reason.
You're not allowed to do that.
So we were so close.
So we know that if we manage to generate the bearer token, then we wouldn't need the whole
interface, the user interface.
We could just issue our own API call programmatically using the bearer token and bypass the whole
thing.
So what do we have so far?
We got guest access.
We found a bunch of credentials on Power Apps.
These are the connections.
I'm reminding you, a connection is connector plus credentials.
And these are shared with me so I can use them.
We tried to access.
We got blocked by a license.
We got a license.
And then we got blocked by DLP.
And we used the pivoted connection.
So we bypassed that as well.
And now we are blocked by programmatic access to the API hub.
So how do we solve that?
We need to find some app on the AAD that we can access to, which is on by default, because
we want it to exist and work in every tenant that we attack.
It has to be pre-approved to query the API hub.
So that's a limited list of apps that are allowed to do that.
Because if you remember, my app and the customer list app, they were not allowed to do that.
And it has to be public, because otherwise I wouldn't be able to access it as a guest.
Now we know that the Power Apps portal can do it.
When we execute an app on our browser, we're doing that through the Power Apps portal.
And we've just seen that that works.
You could copy the bearer token from the browser session and use it outside.
And that worked.
So that's a very good connection.
But we can't generate tokens on its behalf.
So we have to be the good user, which generates a token.
And then we can use the token as the bad user.
So that's not a solution to our problem.
And here comes an excellent research done by the guys at Secureworks.
It's called Family of Client IDs.
And it turns out that there is a list of pre-approved applications, which if you authenticate it
to one of them, Microsoft lets you trade your access token with an access token to the other
one.
And it's undocumented.
The researchers found it.
As always, like all researchers do, they saw that they can move between applications.
And they weren't asked to re-authenticate.
And they started asking why.
And that's how they found it.
So it's really cool.
And this is the list.
These are all members of the one big happy family.
And the two that are interesting to us is the Power Apps, which is the interface that
we're reusing, and the Azure CLI.
Because that we can use.
Right?
I can use it anywhere, particularly on my own tenant.
Right?
So what we're going to do is we're going to use the Microsoft Azure CLI to get a token.
And then we're going to use this undocumented method to trade that token to the API hub
token through the Power Apps that we're not supposed to have.
But it turns out that you can exchange it.
So this is sort of a privilege escalation thing.
OK?
So when you try to do that, it's going to say you need to authenticate.
So I authenticate to the Azure CLI.
And then we go from there.
What happens there?
This is a tool that we created at Zenity.
It is open source.
You can download it, play around with it, contribute to it.
We would appreciate that a lot.
And it can do a lot of things on top of domains that you are a guest at.
Here we're just going to cover two, the dump and the GUI.
OK?
The dump lets you do the recon and basically enumerate on all the resources of the tenant.
And that gives you a lot of attack surface when you're a guest.
And the GUI, the graphical user interface, is just an easy way that we created for you
to analyze your loot, what you actually created.
Now you execute it as a command line.
This is the tenant ID.
And this is the victim tenant, the Zenity demo for our purposes.
And once you do that, you will be asked to authenticate.
And of course, I am a guest at the Zenity demo tenant, so I can do that.
And this is the result of the data collection.
We have credentials, automations, applications, and connectors.
And of course, the things that we are interested in the most
are the connections because they include credentials.
Remember, I keep saying that because it's very important to understand that.
A connection is connector plus credentials.
And these are the connections that we found.
If you remember the list from the beginning,
this is the exact same list that I saw when I first logged into the tenant.
These are shared with the entire organization.
This is why our tool was able to access them and download them.
And you can see here that each one of them has an option of dumping.
This is something we provide to you.
So if you look at the SQL and you look at dump,
you will get to the dump of the database.
Our tool already did that for you.
So there is a dump of all the values in that SQL database
because there is an authenticated connection.
There is a session, a live session, with that database.
And it is shared with us as guests.
So we just used it.
And we just read the whole database.
You can also use the playground.
The playground lets you generate the swagger.
And you can pretty much do anything you want.
So this is not just read.
Anything that the connector exposes as a functionality, you can now use.
So SQL, you can generate and execute any arbitrary query.
You can do basically whatever you want.
Now, how do you protect against that?
Because it's easy to say how to attack.
But how do you defend?
There's a big problem.
In the past, this was the division of responsibility
between the platform and the customer.
The platform took care of the runtime identity.
And the customer was in charge of code, access, business logic, and data.
But now, in low-code, no-code, this is changing
because people are using the platform to generate code.
They're not aware of it.
They don't really know.
Business users are, by definition, people who are not developers.
